Title: Proof that Conditional of Poisson distribution is Binomial
Content:
The classic example... $X \sim Po\left (\lambda\right ), Y \sim Po\left (\mu\right)$ , X and Y are independent.  Show that the conditional distribution of X is binomially distributed. Or in other words, $P(X=k\mid X+Y = n) = P (\tilde{X} = k), \tilde{X} \sim B\left (n ,\frac{\lambda}{\lambda + \mu}\right )$ . I've so far managed to reach to this step, and have been stuck since. Just somehow gotta get a $\frac{1}{n!}$ in the denominator, that would then complete the proof..or at least I think.. $$P(X=k\mid X+Y=n) = \frac{\frac{\lambda^{k}\mu^{n-k}}{k!(n-k)!}}{P(X+Y = n)}=
 \frac{\frac{\lambda^{k}\mu^{n-k}}{k!(n-k)!}}{\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\lambda^{i}\mu^{n-i}}{i!(n-i)!}}$$ Thanks for the help!
AcceptedAnswer:
HINT Remember that $$\sum_{i=0}^{n} \binom{n}{i} \lambda^i \mu^{n-i} = \left( \lambda + \mu\right)^n$$
The above gives us that
$$\sum_{i=0}^{n} \dfrac{n!}{i! (n-i)!} \lambda^i \mu^{n-i} = \left( \lambda + \mu\right)^n$$
which inturn gives us that
$$\sum_{i=0}^{n} \dfrac{ \lambda^i \mu^{n-i}}{i! (n-i)!} = \dfrac{\left( \lambda + \mu\right)^n}{n!}$$

Assumption: 
$X$ follows a Poisson distribution with parameter $\lambda$,
$Y$ follows a Poisson distribution with parameter $\mu$,
$X$ and $Y$ are independent,
The conditional probability is defined as $P(X=k \mid X+Y=n)$.
Problem: 
Prove that the conditional distribution of $X$ given $X+Y=n$ is binomial, i.e.,  
$$P(X=k \mid X+Y=n) = \binom{n}{k} \left(\frac{\lambda}{\lambda+\mu}\right)^k \left(\frac{\mu}{\lambda+\mu}\right)^{n-k},$$  
where $\tilde{X} \sim B\left(n, \frac{\lambda}{\lambda+\mu}\right)$.
###END_OF_FORMAT###

First, I recall that when you have two independent Poisson random variables, their sum X+Y is also Poisson with parameter λ+μ. That's a key property of Poisson distributions. So P(X+Y = n) should be e^{-(λ+μ)} (λ+μ)^n / n! . 

Looking at the user's attempt, they have the conditional probability written as the joint probability divided by the marginal probability of X+Y=n. The joint probability P(X=k, Y=n-k) is the product of P(X=k) and P(Y=n-k) since X and Y are independent. Each of those is a Poisson probability mass function: e^{-λ} λ^k /k! * e^{-μ} μ^{n−k}/(n−k)! . Multiplying those gives e^{-(λ+μ)} λ^k μ^{n−k} / (k! (n−k)!) . 

Then the denominator P(X+Y=n) is indeed e^{-(λ+μ)} (λ+μ)^n / n! . So substituting these into the conditional probability formula, we have:

P(X=k | X+Y=n) = [e^{-(λ+μ)} λ^k μ^{n−k} / (k! (n−k)!)] / [e^{-(λ+μ)} (λ+μ)^n / n! ]

The e^{-(λ+μ)} terms cancel out. Then we can rearrange the remaining terms as [λ^k μ^{n−k} / (k! (n−k)!)) ] * [n! / (λ+μ)^n ].

Simplifying, n! / (k! (n−k)!) is the binomial coefficient C(n,k), so this becomes C(n,k) * (λ^k μ^{n−k}) / (λ+μ)^n . 

We can factor out (λ/(λ+μ))^k * (μ/(λ+μ))^{n−k}, which is the form of a binomial distribution with probability p = λ/(λ+μ) and n trials. Therefore, the conditional distribution is Binomial(n, λ/(λ+μ)).

So when we divide numerator by denominator, the e^{-(λ+μ)} terms cancel, and we get [λ^k μ^{n−k}/(k! (n−k)!)] / [(λ+μ)^n /n!] = [n! / (k! (n−k)!)] * [λ^k μ^{n−k}/(λ+μ)^n] = C(n,k) (λ/(λ+μ))^k (μ/(λ+μ))^{n−k}, which is the binomial PMF. So the user's confusion might be in not recognizing that the sum in the denominator actually evaluates to the Poisson PMF, which allows simplification.
